_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT NORTHERN AG SERVICE, INC.,                    WEST UNION, IA.:

This facility complies with ANSI Standards for Anhydrous Ammonia storage.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the West Union Fire Dept. ( a 911 call ) and request a response to the emergency.  A follow-up call will be made to the Fayette Co. LEPC.

A real emergency will be unexpected and may be very different in nature from any training in the past.  However, any previous planning/training will serve as guidelines to follow.

The primary emergency coordinator is Randy Osmundson.  His work and 24 hr. Emergency number  is listed in the Registration Section of this document  Additional contacts are listed below in order:
        Randy Osmundson, owner
        Work:  (563) 422-6281    24hr: (563) 419-9110

        Ron Seitz, operations
        Work:  (563) 422-6281    24hr:  (563) 419-9107

        Scott Peterson. Agronomy    
        Work:  (563) 422-6281    24hr:  (563) 419-9111

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE  HANDLED AT NORTHERN AG SERVICE, INC.:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant.  The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

The system consists of (1) 30,000 gal storage tank with associated piping, valves, etc., as well as several portable tank units.  The anhydrous ammonia plant is operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall).

THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS:

The worst-case scenario is the failure of the 30,000 gal tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form.  The distance to endpoint is 3.8 miles.

The a

lternative release scenario scenario involves a transfer hose failure.  The resulting release has a distance to endpoint of  .6 miles.

If necessary, area notification and evacuation would be coordinated by the local police and fire department.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA, State and local codes and regulations.  The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standards and State law.

In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Northern Ag Service, Inc. encourages local officials to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant and to become familiar with specific anhydrous ammonia health hazards.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

Northern Ag Service, Inc., West Union, Iowa has not experienced accidental release involving anhydrous ammonia in the last five years that caused death, injuries,  evacuations, property or environmental damage.


THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of Northern Ag Service, Inc., to immediately contact the West Union Fire Deptl and the Fayette County LEPC.  Members of the fire department and the LEPC are invited to regularly visit and inspect our anhydrous ammonia plant.  In addition, photographs of our plant have been made available to the local fire and police departments.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Our overall plan is to minimize hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Employees working with the anhydrous ammonia system make routine observations and inspections prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to nurse tanks, enabling them to detect problems early before they can cause a hazardous situation.  Empl

oyees are trained annually to recognize areas of potential hazards and new hires are trained immediately and observed to determine their level of comprehension and understanding.  The company makes every effort to cooperate with local, state, and federal officials as they endeavor to assist us our anhydrous ammonia operation.
